questions.question: What is the area, in square meters, of a rectangle with a length of 9 meters and a width of 4 meters?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. The area <math><mi>A</mi></math> of a rectangle is given by the formula <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math>, where <math><mi>l</mi></math> represents the length of the rectangle and <math><mi>w</mi></math> represents its width. Substituting 9 for <math><mi>l</mi></math> and 4 for <math><mi>w</mi></math> in the formula <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math> yields <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, or 36. Thus, the area, in square meters, of the rectangle is 36.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that the area of a rectangle is the product of its length and width, not the sum.

questions.question: The side length of a square is 5 centimeters. What is the area, in square centimeters, of the square?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. The area <math><mi>A</mi></math> of a square with side length <math><mi>s</mi></math> is given by the formula <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Substituting 5 for <math><mi>s</mi></math> in the formula <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> yields <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, or 25. Therefore, the area, in square centimeters, of the square is 25.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The area of a square is the side length squared; avoid confusing it with the perimeter, which is four times the side length.

questions.question: Triangle P has an area of 12 square inches. Square Q has side lengths of 3 inches. What is the total area, in square inches, of triangle P and square Q?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. The area of square Q is <math><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, or 9 square inches. Therefore, the total area of triangle P and square Q is 12 + 9, or 21 square inches.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the total area, calculate each shape's area separately and then add them together.

questions.question: A right rectangular prism has a volume of 60 cubic units and a height of 5 units. What is the area, in square units, of the base?
questions.explanation: The volume <math><mi>V</mi></math> of a right rectangular prism is given by <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mi>h</mi></math>, where <math><mi>l</mi></math> and <math><mi>w</mi></math> are the length and width of the base, and <math><mi>h</mi></math> is the height. The area of the base is <math><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math>. Substituting the given values yields 60 = <math><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Dividing both sides by 5 yields <math><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The base area of a prism is the volume divided by the height.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 150,50 250,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='12'>M</text><text x='145' y='40' font-size='12'>N</text><text x='245' y='265' font-size='12'>O</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle MNO with base MO and height from N to base MO.
questions.question: In the figure shown, triangle MNO has a base of 10 units and a height of 6 units. What is the area, in square units, of triangle MNO?
questions.explanation: Choice B is correct. The area of a triangle is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> times base times height, so <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 150,50 250,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><line x1='150' y1='50' x2='150' y2='250' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='12'>M</text><text x='145' y='40' font-size='12'>N</text><text x='245' y='265' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='155' y='150' font-size='12'>height = 6</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangle MNO with dashed line indicating height from N to base MO.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For triangles, ensure you identify the base and corresponding height correctly from the figure.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has a radius of 3 units and a height of 7 units. What is the volume, in cubic units, of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. The volume is <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>63</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember to square the radius when calculating the volume of a cylinder.

questions.question: The length of each edge of a box is 10 inches. Each side of the box is in the shape of a square. The box does not have a lid. What is the exterior surface area, in square inches, of this box without a lid?
questions.explanation: Choice B is correct. The box has 5 faces, each with area <math><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math> square inches, so total surface area is <math><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>500</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For open boxes, subtract the area of the missing face from the total surface area of a closed box.

questions.question: What is the length of one side of a square that has the same area as a circle with radius 4 units?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. The area of the circle is <math><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. For the square, <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, so <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msqrt><mi>π</mi></msqrt></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When equating areas, solve for the side length by taking the square root after setting the areas equal.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has a volume of <math><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi></math> cubic units. If the height of the cylinder is 4 units, what is the radius of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: The volume is <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. Substituting 4 for <math><mi>h</mi></math> gives <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. Dividing by <math><mi>π</mi></math> yields <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>. Dividing by 4 yields <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Taking the positive square root yields <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the radius squared before taking the square root in cylinder volume problems.

questions.question: Square R has a side length of 8 centimeters. The area of square S is 4 times the area of square R. What is the length, in centimeters, of one side of square S?
questions.explanation: The area of square R is <math><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math>. The area of square S is <math><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>256</mn></math>. The side length is <math><msqrt><mn>256</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When areas scale by a factor, side lengths scale by the square root of that factor.

questions.question: Square T has side lengths that are 5 times the side lengths of square U. The area of square T is <math><mi>k</mi></math> times the area of square U. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Choice D is correct. Areas scale with the square of the linear dimensions, so <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In scaling problems, remember that areas scale by the square of the scale factor for lengths.

questions.question: A right square prism has a height of 10 units. The volume of the prism is 360 cubic units. What is the length, in units, of an edge of the base?
questions.explanation: Choice B is correct. Volume is <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>360</mn></math>, so <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>, <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve for the base edge by taking the square root after dividing volume by height.

questions.question: The circumference of the base of a right circular cylinder is 12<math><mi>π</mi></math> meters, and the height of the cylinder is 5 meters. What is the volume, in cubic meters, of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. Circumference <math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Volume <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find the radius from the circumference before calculating the volume.

questions.question: A cube has an edge length of 10 inches. A solid sphere with a radius of 5 inches is inside the cube, such that the sphere touches the center of each face of the cube. To the nearest cubic inch, what is the volume of the space in the cube not taken up by the sphere?
questions.explanation: Choice B is correct. Cube volume <math><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn></math>. Sphere volume <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>≈</mo><mn>524</mn></math>. Difference 1000 - 524 = 476? Wait, recalculate: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>125</mn><mo>≈</mo><mn>523.6</mn></math>, 1000 - 524 ≈ 476. But options have 476 as A. Wait, if sphere touches centers, diameter = edge, r=5 yes. Volume sphere ≈523.6, 1000-523.6≈476.4, nearest 476.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Subtract the sphere's volume from the cube's volume after confirming the radius fits the description.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 100,100 150,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><polygon points='200,250 300,50 400,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='95' y='90' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='145' y='265' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='190' y='265' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='295' y='40' font-size='12'>E</text><text x='395' y='265' font-size='12'>F</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two similar triangles ABC and DEF, with AB corresponding to DE.
questions.question: In the figure shown, triangle ABC is similar to triangle DEF, where A corresponds to D and B corresponds to E. The length of AC is 8 units, and the perimeter of triangle ABC is 24 units. The length of DF is 12 units. What is the perimeter of triangle DEF?
questions.explanation: Choice B is correct. Corresponding sides are AC to DF, ratio 8/12 = 2/3. Perimeters scale by same factor, so perimeter DEF = 24 / (2/3) = 36.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 100,100 150,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><polygon points='200,250 300,50 400,250' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='40' y='265' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='95' y='90' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='145' y='265' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='190' y='265' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='295' y='40' font-size='12'>E</text><text x='395' y='265' font-size='12'>F</text><text x='100' y='270' font-size='12'>scale 2:3</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangles ABC and DEF with scale factor indicated.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For similar figures, perimeters scale with the side lengths, while areas scale with the square.

questions.question: A cone has a height of 9 units and a base radius of 4 units. What is the volume, in cubic units, of the cone?
questions.explanation: Choice A is correct. Volume of cone is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>48</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Don't forget the 1/3 factor in the cone volume formula.

questions.question: A sphere has a radius of 6 units. What is the surface area, in square units, of the sphere?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. Surface area is <math><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>144</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Surface area of a sphere uses 4πr², distinct from volume's (4/3)πr³.

questions.question: A rectangular prism has dimensions 3 by 4 by 5 units. What is the surface area, in square units?
questions.explanation: Choice C is correct. Surface area = 2(lw + lh + wh) = 2(12 + 15 + 20) = 2(47) = 94.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Calculate each pair of faces separately for prism surface area.

questions.question: A pyramid has a square base with side length 6 units and height 8 units. What is the volume, in cubic units, of the pyramid?
questions.explanation: Volume = <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> × base area × height = <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>96</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Base area for a square pyramid is side squared.

questions.question: The volume of a sphere is <math><mn>288</mn><mi>π</mi></math> cubic units. What is the radius of the sphere?
questions.explanation: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>288</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. Divide by <math><mi>π</mi></math>: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>288</mn></math>. Multiply by 3/4: <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>216</mn></math>. Cube root: <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find radius from volume, take the cube root after isolating r³.
